This study investigates the epoxidation of styrene using efficient photochromic heterogeneous catalysts, specifically SBA-15-N-CoL₁ and SBA-15-N-MnL₁. Styrene oxide is a vital intermediate in the chemical industry, utilized in pharmaceuticals and polymers. Traditional homogeneous catalysts for styrene epoxidation face limitations, including difficulty in separation and recycling. This research focuses on the development of metal-organic complexes with photochromic properties to enhance catalytic efficiency and light responsiveness. Factors such as temperature, reaction time, amount of catalyst and an oxidant were systematically examined to optimize the catalytic performance. The results indicate that these heterogeneous catalysts achieved high conversion rates of styrene, with selectivity for styrene oxide reaching up to 85 %. Additionally, they demonstrated excellent stability and reusability, maintaining their catalytic activity over four consecutive cycles. This underscores their potential in promoting efficient chemical processes and advancing sustainable practices in the epoxidation of styrene. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key words Functionalized mesoporous silica Metallosalphen complexes Grafting-coordination method Photochromic Catalaysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Styrene oxide is a crucial intermediate in the chemical industry, serving as a versatile building block in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, and polymers (Scheme 1 ) [1,2]. Over the past few decades, considerable efforts have been made to develop simple and efficient catalysts for styrene epoxidation. Transition metal-based catalysts, particularly organotransition metal complexes (OTMC), have been extensively investigated for styrene epoxidation [3–5]. Among these catalysts, metallosalphen complexes demonstrate high activity [6,7]. These complexes are metal-organic compounds where metal ions are coordinated to tetradentate [O, N, N, O] bis-Schiff base ligands, which exhibit strong coordination abilities and are easily synthesized [8]. As a result, they are considered highly effective catalysts for various applications, including the oxidation of hydrocarbons [9–13]. To develop sustainable catalysts, one promising strategy involves modifying salphen ligands by incorporating a photochromic group [14]. This modification enhances the light-responsive properties of the catalyst [15,16]. Azobenzene derivatives are known for their significant applications, particularly their ability to undergo cis/trans photoisomerization, which is valuable in optics, photochemistry, and biomaterials [17–19]. By inserting this photochromic moiety into the salphen ligand, the resulting organometallic catalyst (OTMC) can acquire new light-responsive functionalities, potentially broadening its utility in various chemical processes and applications [20,21]. Transition metal complexes catalysts (e.g., Co, Mn, and Ni) can achieve high selectivity for epoxides and effective conversion of styrene [22,23]. However, these homogeneous complexes face several limitations, including challenges in separating the catalyst from the reaction mixture and poor recycling capabilities [24]. In contrast to homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous systems offer several advantages, including easier separation from reaction mixtures and the ability to be reused over multiple cycles [25,26]. Consequently, the heterogenization of metalosalphen complexes is particularly important. By combining the benefits of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, this approach aims to develop highly efficient catalytic systems [27,28]. Various solid materials, such as nanoporous carbon, zeolites, clays, and resins, are widely used as supports in homogeneous systems [29–34]. Mesoporous silica materials, including MCM-41, MCM-48, and SBA-15, are considered efficient supports due to their high surface areas, large pore sizes, controllable pore size, high hydrothermal stability, and ease of functionalization [35–37]. Amino-functionalized silica and mesoporous silica are emerging materials for catalytic supports [38,39]. Recently, our group reported efficient Silica-N-ML catalysts (Silica: SBA-15, MCM-41, and MCM-48; M: Co, Mn, Ni, Cu) for the oxidation of cyclohexane. Among these catalysts, SBA-15-N-ML (M: Co and Mn) exhibited excellent activity, achieving 93 % conversion and 92 % selectivity over m-CPBA [40]. Building on previous research utilizing SBA-15-N-ML catalysts for the oxidation of cyclohexane, the focus now shifts to evaluating their performance specifically in the epoxidation of styrene. This study aims to achieve promising results by enhancing the catalytic efficiency, improving selectivity toward styrene oxide, and promoting sustainable practices in the epoxidation of styrene. In this study, we selected SBA-15-N-ML (M: Co and Mn) as catalysts for the epoxidation of styrene under ambient conditions using tert‑Butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as the oxygen donor. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Sodium nitrite (NaNO2) (99.99 %), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) (≥ 98 %), ortho-Vanillin (99 %), Salicylaldehyde (98 %), Aniline (99.5 %), o-phenylenediamine (99.5 %), and acetic acid glacial (> 99.5 %) were used as the starting materials for the preparation of ligand H2L1 . The metal salts employed Cobalt (II) acetate tetrahydrate Co(CO2CH3)2·4H2O) (≥98 %), Manganese (II) acetate tetrahydrate Mn(CO2CH3)2.(4H2O) (98 %).The solvents used in this study, such as Ethanol absolute (99.8 %), Chloroform (99.9 %), Chloroform (99.9 %), Diethyl ether (99 %), Ether (>90 %) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Characterization The synthesized catalysts were characterized using a range of analytical techniques. Infrared spectra were recorded with a FTIR spectrometer (Bruker Vector 22) in the range of 4000 to 500 cm⁻¹. UV–Vis spectra were obtained using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer (UV-160 A Shimadzu), measuring absorbance from 200 to 800 nm in chloroform. Melting points were determined with an MSRS apparatus. Proton and carbon nuclear magnetic resonance spectra (¹H and ¹³C NMR) were acquired in DMSO‑d6 using a Bruker AMx 600 MHz spectrometer. The elemental compositions of the compounds were analyzed with a CHN Elemental Analyzer (Vario MICRO), while metal percentages in the complexes were measured using Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectroscopy (ICP-MS 2030LF SHIMADZU). Thermal stability was confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a Thermo Fisher Q50 instrument, with samples heated from 30 to 800 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD) was employed to evaluate crystallinity and dispersion of [ML1] within the SBA-15 matrix. The specific surface area and pore characteristics were determined using a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 analyzer. Morphological features of the SBA-15-N-ML1 particles were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7100F), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-1400Plus) was utilized to capture detailed images of the prepared samples. 2.3 Preparation of catalysts 2.3.1 Synthesis of the salphen azobenzene ligand N,N’-bis[5-(phenylazo)-2-hydroxybenzal]−1,2-phenylene diamine H2L1 was synthesized according to the procedure reported previously [40].The synthesis involved the preparation of the azobenzene aldehyde intermediate 2a. First, 0.91 ml (0.010 mol) of aniline was dissolved in 12 mL of an aqueous solution of hydrochloric acid to form solution I. In a separate flask, 1.03 g (0.015 mol) of sodium nitrite was dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water at 0–5 °C to yield solution II. Solution II was then added dropwise to solution I at 0–5 °C, and the resulting diazonium salt mixture was stirred for 30 min at 0–5 °C. Concurrently, in 250 mL flask 1.04 mL (0.010 mol) of salicylaldehyde was dissolved in 10 mL (0.010 mol) of 10 % sodium hydroxide solution, then the temperature was cooled down to 0–5 °C. Then the diazonium salt solution was slowly added to the salicylaldehyde solution. The obtained mixture was stirred at 0–5 °C for 2 h, to afford the precipitation of compound 2a as a yellowish solid. The obtained 2‑hydroxy-5-[(E)-phenyldiazenyl] benzaldehyde (2a) was collected via filtration, dried overnight. In a 1 L two-neck round-bottom flask with a magnetic stirrer and reflux condenser, 5.0 g of commercial SBA-15 silica was dispersed in 650 ml of toluene. At 70 °C and under vigorous stirring, 1.75 ml (7.5 mmol) of APTES was added dropwise. The mixture was maintained at 70 °C for 15 h. The resulting product, SBA-15-N, was separated by filtration, thoroughly washed with toluene and ethanol to remove excess APTES, and dried in an oven at 80 °C. 2.3.4 Immobilisation of metallosalphen azobenzene complex onto SBA-15-N surface The metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1] were immobilized onto the surface of amino-functionalized silica material (SBA-15-N), according to a procedure reported previously [40]. First, 1.0 g of amino-functionalized was dispersed in 100 mL of EtOH/CH2Cl2 (2:1 v/v) in a 250 mL flask. Then, 0.5 g of [ML1] complex (M: Co, Mn) was added to the mixture. After stirring the mixture at 50 °C for 15 h. The catalysts were obtained after filtration and washing three times with CH2Cl2 and EtOH to remove any excess of free (non-coordinated) [ML1] complex and dried overnight at 80 °C for 15 h. The prepared catalysts were denoted as SBA-15-N-ML1 (M: Mn, Co). 2.4 Catalytic performance study 2.4.1 Epoxidation of styrene The epoxidation of styrene was carried out in a 50 mL two-neck round bottom flask connected to a condenser, and 100 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 5 mL of acetonitrile to create the reaction medium. Following this, 1.1 mL (10 mmol) of styrene (STE), 1.0 mL (10 mmol) of bromobenzene (IS), and 2 equivalents amount of TBHP were introduced into the mixture. The resulting mixture was then heated at 60 °C for 4 h to facilitate the reaction. The progress of the epoxidation reaction of styrene was monitored using GC, type Shimadzu GC-2014, equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID), using FFAP 15 % C W60/80 column, with 4.0 m in length, and 0.32 mm in diameter, with a 1 μm film thickness. Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas, at a flow rate of 35 mL/min. Samples of 1 μL were withdrawn periodically form the reaction mixture to be injected into GC. The temperature program of the GC oven was as follows: the temperature initially held at 120.0 °C for 1 min, then increased to 150.0 °C with 20.00 °C/min, then held for 10 min at 150.0 °C. The temperature was subsequently increased to 280.00 °C with a rate of 50.00 °C/min, with another 4 min hold at 280.0 °C. The injector temperature was maintained at 190.0 °C, and the temperature of FID was set at 300.0 °C for consistent analysis. To quantify the reaction products using gas GC, calibration curves were established for styrene, and styrene oxide Figure S1 Standard mixtures containing known concentrations of each analyte (styrene, styrene oxide), along with an internal standard (IS) (bromobenzene), were prepared and injected into the GC. Peak area ratios were calculated for each analyte relative to the internal standard. Calibration plots were then constructed by graphing these peak area ratios against the moles of analyte injected. Separated calibration curves were obtained for styrene (Fig S1a), styrene oxide (Fig S1b). From these calibration plots, the response factors of each analyte relative to the internal standard could be determined. The derived response factors from the standard calibrations were subsequently used to quantitatively analyze reaction mixtures. This allowed the calculation of the products selectivity, and the substrate conversion via GC analysis using the response factors obtained from the calibration standards. The conversion of styrene (STE) and the selectivity of styrene oxide (STEO) were determined using the following equations: Conversion of STE ( % ) = [ STE ] 0 − [ STE ] t [ STE ] 0 × 100 Where [ STE ] 0 is the initial styrene concentration, [ STE ] t is the concentration of styrene after time t. Selectivity of STEO ( % ) = [ STEO ] t [ STE ] 0 − [ STE ] t × 100 where [STEO]t is the styrene oxide concentration after time t. 2.4.2 Catalyst reuse and stability The recyclability of the catalysts was evaluated through four consecutive runs. After each cycle, the used catalyst was filtered out from the reaction mixture. It was then agitated in 10 mL of chloroform for 30 min. Following this, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and dried at 70 °C for 15 h, preparing it for the subsequent cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The salphen-azobenzene ligands H2L1 was prepared via a mutli-steps synthesis pathway following a previously reported procedure [40]. The first step consists of the synthesis of the azobenzene precursors 2a. This was achieved via the formation of the benzene diazonium chloride ion by diazotization of the aniline in the presence of sodium nitrile and HCl at 0–5 °C, followed by a coupling reaction between the benzene diazonium chloride ion and salicylaldehyde (1a) in the presence of NaOH, to afford the corresponding azobenzene product 2a. The mechanism of diazotization of aniline involves the generation of nitrous acid HNO2 after the treatment of sodium nitrile (NaNO2) with aqueous HCl. Then, HNO2 formed was also protonated to form the corresponding oxonium ion, which has a good leaving group H2O. The elimination of H2O molecule generated the nitrosonium ion. The lone pair of the nitrogen atom of aniline attacked the nitrosonium ion, followed by deprotonation of the formed intermediate by H2O molecule to afford the corresponding N-nitrosoamine. After the protonation of the oxygen atom of nitroso group and deprotonation of NH group in N-nitrosoamine, followed dehydration, the benzene diazonium chloride ion was formed [39,40]. The mechanism of the coupling reaction between the obtained diazonium salt and salicylaldehyde is illustrated below. This process occurs via an electrophilic aromatic substitution reaction, with the diazonium ion acting as the electrophile. This substitution was directed by the hydroxyl group in its para position, as the -OH group is a stronger activating group than -CHO. The mechanism consists of two steps: the first step involves the addition of the diazonium ion to form a resonance-stabilized carbocation, while the second step is rearomatization, which yields the desired azobenzene 2a. 2a [43,44]. The prepared azobenzene 2a subsequently undergoes a Schiff-base condensation reaction with o-phenylenediamine to produce ligand H2L1 . The formation of salphen-azobenzene ligands H2L1 was confirmed by FT-IR, UV–Vis,1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopic techniques. The FT-IR spectra of the intermediate 2a and ligand H2L1 are presented in Figure S2 (a, b). The spectrum of the compound 2a (Fig. S2 (a)) exhibited a peak at 1472 cm−1 (□ ) assigned to the stretching vibration of the azo group N = N. The carbonyl stretching bond was observed at around 1665 cm−1(■). In addition, the stretching vibrations of the aromatic C = C appeared at 1580 cm −1(□). Moreover, the stretching vibrations of the aromatic CH (▲) were observed at around 3130 cm−1 (□). This result was consistent with the literature [45], which confirmed the structure of the intermediate 2a. However, the carbonyl stretching vibration observed at 1665 cm−1 in 2a spectrum disappeared in the spectrum of ligand H2L1 (Fig. S2 (b)), with the appearance of a new peak at 1606 cm−1 ( ⊙ ) attributed to the imine (C = N) stretching vibration. This confirmed the conversion of the intermediate 2a to the intended H2L1 ligand. The UV–Vis absorption spectra were recorded between 250 and 700 nm for compound 2a and the salphen-azobenzene ligand H2L1 in chloroform, with a concentration of 5 10⁻⁶ mol·L⁻¹ at room temperature. As shown in Figure S3, compound 2a displayed characteristic π-π* (trans) and n-π* (cis) transition peaks of the azobenzene moiety at around 330 nm and 445 nm, respectively. While ligand H2L1 exhibited red-shifted and broader absorption bands, with main peaks at around 350 nm, attributed to the transitions π-π*. These results clearly illustrated the effect of the conjugation extension in the structure of the prepared salphen-azobenzene ligand. This is consistent with literature showing extended conjugation leads to red-shifting [46]. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra of the intermediate 2a are presented in Figure S4, and Figure S5, respectively. The 1H NMR spectrum of the intermediate 2a displayed eight signals, which is consistent with the proposed structure. A singlet appears at δ 11.53 ppm (s,1H, OH) attributable to the proton of the to the hydroxide group. Another singlet peak is observed at 10.38 (s, 1H, CHO), corresponding to the aldehyde proton (proton 1). The region from δ 7–8.3 ppm integrates for eight protons, corresponding to the two benzene rings protons. The singlet signal observed at 8.20 ppm corresponding to proton 7. Protons 5 and 4 appeared as double signals at 8.11 ppm and 7. 20 ppm, respectively, with J = 8.12 Hz. Proton 4 was shielded due to hydroxyl group. Protons 9 and 9′ appeared as a doublet at 7.88 ppm with a J = 7.5 Hz. protons 10 and 10′ observed at 7.59 ppm as a triplet. While signal of proton 11 appeared as quadruplet due to the lone pairs of the azo nitrogen atoms which are pointing toward protons 10 and 10′ differently, which made these two protons looks different for proton 11. It has to be noted that the triplet signal of proton 10 was overlapped with the quadruplet signal of proton 11. The 13C NMR spectrum of compound 2a (Fig. S5) displayed the aromatic carbons appear in the region from δ 163.82 ppm to 118.90 ppm. Furthermore, the carbon of the aldehyde group was seen at δ 191.01 ppm, while the carbon of hydroxide group appeared at 163.82 ppm. Moreover, the DEPT 45 carbon NMR experiments were conducted, and the obtained spectrum showed the nine CH carbons, while the four quaternary carbons did not appear (Fig S5). These results confirmed the structure of the intermediate 2a. The structure of ligand H2L1 was characterized also by 1H and 13C NMR. The obtained spectra are presented in Figures S6 and S7, respectively. The 1H NMR spectrum showed a broad singlet peak at δ 13.40 ppm attributed to two hydroxyl protons. While the peak corresponding to the aldehyde proton (CHO) was present in 2a at δ 10.38 ppm, disappeared in ligand H2L1 spectrum. Moreover, a new sharp singlet peak appeared at δ 8.43 ppm, integrated for two protons, assigned to the protons of the new azomethines (imines) groups (proton 1). Further support for the intended structure was provided by multiplets between δ 9.23 ppm - 7.12 ppm, accounting precisely for 20 protons, associated with the intended aromatic rings of the azobenzene moieties and o-phenylenediamine ring. Additionally, the aromatic proton peaks, particularly protons 4, 5, and 7 of the azobenzene unit in the intermediate 2a were shifted downfield in the ligand, due to the shielding effect of the nearby electron-rich nitrogen in the azomethine group, in addition to the electron delocalization after the formation of the ligand H2L1 . The 13C NMR spectrum of the ligand H2L1 (Fig. S7) displayed all expected signals corresponding to the aromatic carbons in the region δ 165.20 ppm −118.72 ppm. In addition, an additional signal observed at δ 163.88 ppm was assigned to the imine carbons (carbon 1). Furthermore, the peak appeared at δ 165.90 ppm was attributed to the phenolic COH carbons (carbon 3). These diagnostic carbon resonances matched the expected structure of ligand H2L1 and confirmed the presence of the key azomethine and phenolic functionalities. The metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1] were synthesized by coordination of the prepared salphen-azobenzene ligands H2L1 to selected transition metal ions, including cobalt (Co (II)), manganese (Mn(II)), following a procedure described previously [40]. These transition metal ions were selected based on their higher catalytic activity on the oxidation reaction of hydrocarbons compared to other transition metals. Ligand H2L1 contains two imine nitrogen atoms (N2), and two phenolic oxygen atoms (O2), in the main complexation cavity, that can share their lone pair electrons with the metal ion. The structure of the prepared [ML1] complexes was confirmed by FT-IR, UV–Vis, elemental analysis ICP, and TGA. Figure S8 shows the obtained FT-IR spectra for complexes [ML1] (M: Co, Mn,). The coordination of Co(II), Mn(II) to ligand H2L1 was confrimed by the shifts of the C = N stretching bands ( ⊙ ) to lower wavenumbers, by 13–25 cm−1 , n [CoL1] and [MnL1] sepctra, compared to H2L1 . The phenolic C–O stretching vibrations appeared at around 1280 cm−1 (Δ) in H2L1 spectrum was shifted towards lower frequencies (by 10–20 cm−1) in the complexes [ML1]. This can be attributed to coordination of the oxygen atom to the metal centers and formation of CO-M bonds. Finally, the apparaition of new weak peaks in the low wavenumber region, 678–674 cm−1 (◊) and 499–506 cm−1 (■) provided additional evidence about the formation of M-O and M-N coordination bonds. Overall, the FT-IR analyses confirmed the successful synthesis of complexes [ML1] (M: Co, Mn). The UV–Vis spectra of the metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1] were recorded in CHCl3 at room temperature. The UV–Vis spectrum of the free salphen-azobenzene ligand H2L1 (Fig S9) shows characteristic π-π* and n-π* transitions at around 350 nm and 450 nm, respectively. Upon complexation with the metal ions Co(II), Mn(II), these transitions were clearly red-shifted. Specifically, the transitions π-π* underwent bathochromic (red) shifts to longer wavelengths by 20–36 nm. This shift can be attributed to two main factors. First, electron donation of the nitrogen atoms lone pair of the imine group (C = N) to the metal centers (N→M) [47]. Second, the disappearance of the intramolecular hydrogen bonding between C = N and OH groups in the free ligand upon metal complexation [48]. This spectral shift provided clear evidence about the successful complexation of the metal ions with ligand H2L1 . This in agreement with the literature [46]. The thermal behavior of the [ML1] complexes was analyzed using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) from 25 to 800 °C in air. As shown in Figure S10, the complexes exhibit two main weight loss. The initial weight observed below 150 °C can be attributed to the evaporation of water and solvents residues. The second weight loss observed below 200 °C attributed to the ligand decomposition. The complexes stability was slightly related to the type of metal center. Cooper complex [CoL1] showed the highest thermal stability compared to [MnL1] complex. The decomposition of cobalt complex started from 188 °C until 267 °C, with a weight loss of 89.8 %. Manganese complex [MnL1] was slightly less stable than cobalt complex, with decomposition temperature ranged from 185 to 263 °C, which corresponding to a weight loss of 90.3 %. In addition, the metal contents calculated from the TGA curves agreement with the calculated and ICP results. The obtained results were probably related to the type of metal center, where the smaller ionic radius of metal allows it to more effectively coordinate with ligand donor groups, forming stronger bonds that confer greater thermal stability. The stepwise thermal decomposition data obtained from TGA curves and the metal content from ICP-MASS for [ML1] complexes are summarized in Table S1. The goal of this work was the synthesis of highly dispersed metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1] (M: Co, Mn) into SBA-15 mesoporous silica, by immobilizing these complexes onto SBA-15 surfaces via grafting/coordination method. In the first step, the commercial mesoporous silica material SBA-15, was functionalized by aminopropyl groups via grafting reaction of APTES on the silica surface (Scheme 2 ). This was achieved through a nucleophilic substitution reaction between the silanol groups present on the silica surface and APTES molecules. In fact, the silanol oxygen atoms acted as nucleophiles, attacking the central silicon of APTES, and displacing ethoxy groups. Concurrently, siloxane bonds were formed between the silica surface and propylamine groups. As the APTES molecule became grafted, ethoxy groups departed in the form of ethanol molecules, and leaving aminopropyl substituents on the silica surface. Repeated process occurred across the accessible silanol sites, yield the amino-functionalized mesoporous silica (SBA-15-N) bearing surface aminopropyl moieties for further complexes [ML1] immobilization. APTES can be grafted on to silica surface either by one, two or three siloxane (Si-O-Si) bonds, while unreacted Si-OEt group of APTES will be transformed to silanol groups (Si-OH), as shown in Scheme 2. In the second step (Scheme 3 ), the metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1] were immobilized into mesoporous SBA-15-N via coordination bond between the aminopropyl groups of APTES grafted on the surface of silica SBA-15-N, and the metal center of complexes [ML1]. In fact, the coordination bond occurred between the empty orbital of the central metal atom (i.e., Co, Mn) of complexes [ML1], which acted as Lewis acid, and the nitrogen atom of the grafted aminopropyl groups, which acted as a N-ligand (Lewis base), and donated its electron lone pair to the metal ion of the complexes [ML1] through a coordination bond. This resulted in the formation of a coordination bond between the metal center and the amine-functionalized silica surfaces, yielding the desired heterogeneous catalyst materials SBA-15-N-ML1. (M: Co, Mn). FT-IR spectroscopy was used to identify the key functional groups present in the SBA-15-N-ML1 samples. After the addition of [ML1] complexes to the amino-functionalized silica materials (SBA-15-N), FT-IR analysis was performed to the prepared SBA-15-N-ML1 (i.e., M: Mn, Co), and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 1 , The intensity of the peaks observed around ∼ 3035 cm−1 (▲) was slightly increased compared to the same peaks in SBA-15-N. This can be due to the additional peaks of CH groups of ligand L1 in complexes [ML1]. The peaks observed at ∼1590 cm−1 (⊙), ∼1570 (●), ∼1430(∆), and ∼ 1290 (◆), can be assigned to C = N, C = C, N = N, and CO bonds of ligand L1 , respectively. The NH bending peak of NH2 group (□) in SBA-15-N was shifted to a lower frequency, ∼ 655 cm−1, after the addition of [ML1] complexes. This can be due to the formation of a coordination bond between the nitrogen atom of NH2 group and metal ions (i.e., Co2+, Mn2+). Moreover, other tiny peaks appeared between 550 and 525 cm−1 (■), can be attributed to Metal-O bonds. The vibration peaks corresponding to Co-O, Mn-O, appeared at ∼540 cm−1, ∼550 cm−1, respectively. N2 adsorption/desorption analysis was used to determine the surface area, pore size, and pore volumes of SBA-15-N-ML1 samples (M: Co, Mn). The surface area and the average pore diameter and pore volume were derived using the BJH method. The obtained results for SBA-15 related samples are shown in Fig. 2 . In addition, the textural characteristics of these samples are summarized in Table 1 . The obtained N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of all samples after the immobilization (Fig. 2a) showed type IV isotherms, with H1 hysteresis loops, which indicating that all the mesoporous structures of the materials were maintained after the modification. After the immobilization of the [ML1] complexes into SBA-15-N, the BET surface area, pore size, and pore volume, were decreased in all samples (Table 1). Specifically, the surface area of the obtained materials SBA15-N-CoL1, SBA15-N-MnL1 was found to be 251 m2/g, 252 m2/g, respectively. Additionally, their pore size was also decreased to 3.89 nm, and 3.93 nm, respectively (Fig. 2b). Furthermore, pore volume of these samples was also reduced to 0.39 cm3/g. This indicated the successful immobilization of the [ML1] complexes into amino-functionalized SBA-15-N. TGA analysis was conducted on SBA-15, before and after the incorporation of the metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1] to investigate their thermal behavior and determine their organic content. The thermogravimetric analysis of SBA-15-N was performed to serve as reference for the final materials SBA-15-N-ML1 . The obtained results are presented in Fig. 3 and summarized in Table 2 . The thermograms of all samples showed three main steps of weight loss. The initial step below 200 °C presents a weight loss of 2–5 %, which is attributed to the physically absorbed solvents and water residues. The second step observed between 220 °C and 600 °C related to the decomposition of the salphen-azobenzene ligand and APTES linker. Notably, the decomposition step of all silica supported [ML1] complexes was started at around 220 °C but extended to around 600 °C, compared to unsupported [ML1] which exhibited a rapid decomposition between 200 °C and 300 °C (Fig. 3). This was due to the silica wall which acted as a thermal insulator for the [ML1] complexes. The third step was observed after 600 °C, and attributed the dehydroxylation reaction of silica surface silanols groups (Si-OH) to form siloxanes groups (Si-O-Si). For SBA-15-N), the APTES-propylamine groups were decomposed between 330–450 °C [49,50], with a weight loss of around 4.5 %.The weight loss observed between 225 °C and 600 °C attributed to the decomposition of the salphen-azobenzene ligand and APTES linker (L + APTES), with an organic weight loss of 13.10 %, 13.60 %, for samples SBA-15-N-MnL1, SBA-15-N-CoL1,respectively. These results were consistent with the ML1 content in silica samples determined by ICP-MASS (Table 2). Scanning electron microscope (SEM) analysis was also used to investigate the particle morphology of SBA-15 material, before and after their functionalization with APTES and immobilization of metallosalphen-azobenzene complexes [ML1]. Fig. 4 present the obtained SEM micrographs. The SEM images (Fig. 4a,b) reveal that the SBA-15 particles consist of worm-like particles that agglomerate into larger microparticles with tubular shapes. The SEM micrographs (Fig. 4c,d) showed also worm-like particles of the amino-functionalized SBA-15-N, with tubular shapes, showing more particles aggregation after grafting APTES onto SBA-15 surface (Fig. 4d). This increase in the aggregation of SBA-15-N particles can be due to the formation of extra hydrogen bonds intra- and inter-particles involving the propylamine groups of APTES. After the immobilization of metallosalphen-azobenzene [ML1] complexes into SBA-15-N, the aggregation level was decreased compared to the large tubular agglomerates previously observed in SBA-15-N. Instead, smaller, and individual microparticles appeared, as are visible in SEM images of materials SBA-15-N-ML1 (M: Mn, Co) (Fig. 4e-h). This can be due to the breaking of the hydrogen bonds involving silica-surface amine groups, and their involvement in coordination bonds with the metal centers. Consequently, this led to the stabilization of SBA-15-N-ML1 material particles. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to visualize the nanostructures and dispersion of [ML1] complexes through the silica surface. The obtained TEM images are presented in Fig. 5 . Images (a) and (b) display the parallel mesoporous channels, characteristic of the highly nano-ordered SBA-15. The TEM images obtained after the incorporation of [CoL1] (Fig. 5c,d) and [MnL1] (Fig. 5e,f) revealed clearly the preservation of the silica nanostructure after surface modifications. More importantly, the absence of any dark spots in the TEM images of SBA-15-N-CoL1 and SBA-15-N-MnL1 samples indicated the high dispersion of [CoL1] and [MnL1] complexes through SBA-15. Powder XRD was performed for samples SBA-15-N and their corresponding silica supported [ML1] complexes SBA-15-N-ML1 (M: Mn, Co). The obtained XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 6 . All samples presented a single broad peak at around 2θ = 22.9°, which is a characteristic of amorphous silica [51]. Notably, no distinctive peaks corresponding to any crystalline phases of complexes [ML1] were observed. This suggested that the [ML1] complexes were highly dispersed through the mesoporous silica surface in all prepared samples. This in agreement with the TEM results described above (Fig. 5). In addition, these findings confirmed our approach to prepare SBA-15-N-ML1 materials with only isolated [ML1] molecules coordinated to isolated surface NH2 groups, and to avoid any aggregation between phase [ML1] molecules, by removing the free molecules (not coordinated to NH2 groups) by filtration and frequent washing process. 3.2 Epoxidation of styrene TBHP is a multifunctional organic peroxide that serves as a key oxidizing agent in organic synthesis [52]. Similar to m-CPBA, TBHP is widely used in various oxidation reactions, especially in industrial settings, thanks to its relatively safe handling and availability in both aqueous and anhydrous forms [53]. Although TBHP is generally less reactive than m-CPBA, it has proven to be effective in oxidizing alcohols and in the epoxidation of olefins. Its cost-effectiveness is a notable advantage, along with its good selectivity in numerous chemical transformations [54]. TBHP can also be activated by different transition metal catalysts [55]. Its stability at room temperature and compatibility with a range of reaction conditions make it particularly well-suited for large-scale industrial applications [56]. In this study, 2 equivalents of TBHP were employed to epoxidize styrene using unsupported complexes [ML1] and SBA-15-N-ML1 catalysts at 60 °C for 4 h. The obtained results are presented in Table 3 . Notably, the reaction showed no conversion in the absence of catalysts (Entry 1). The unsupported complexes [ML1] (Entries 2 and 3) achieved styrene conversion rates between 52 % and 55 %, with selectivity for styrene oxide around 50 % . In contrast, the heterogeneous catalysts SBA-15-N-CoL1 (Entry 3) and SBA-15-N-MnL1 (Entry 4) exhibited significantly higher styrene conversion rates of 85 % and 83 %, respectively, along with selectivity for styrene oxide of 87 % and 83 %.This enhancement in catalytic efficiency is likely attributed to the larger pore size of SBA-15, which facilitates better dispersion of the complexes [ML1] and improves the diffusion of reactants [57]. Furthermore, the thicker silica walls of SBA-15, contribute to greater mechanical stability of the catalyst [58,59]. The results obtained with TBHP were compared to various catalysts reported in the literature (Entries 6–9). For instance, SBA-15 supported cobalt oxide nanoparticles (SBA-15-Co3O4) was prepared through the physical interaction of Co(NO3)2·6H2O with SBA-15, followed by chemical coordination with isonicotinic acid to achieve 14 % (wt. %) oxide loading. This method resulted in lower conversion (80 %) and selectivity (74 %) even at 70 °C (Entry 6) [60]. In another case, SBA-15 supported manganese nanoparticles (SBA-15-Mn) was synthesized using a co-precipitation method, where aqueous solutions of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O was incorporated into SBA-15. The resulting SBA-15-Mn catalyst showed a conversion of styrene to styrene oxide, achieving 96 % conversion and 64 % selectivity after extending the reaction time to 7 h at 60 °C (Entry 7) [61]. When manganese was substituted with copper (SBA-15-Cu) (Entry 8), the catalytic activity decreased further, yielding only 74 % conversion and 78 % selectivity under the same conditions [61]. Additionally, silica-supported nickel-based organometallic complexes were evaluated for the epoxidation of styrene. For example, the MCM-41 supported nickel Schiff base complex (MCM-41-NiL) was synthesized by anchoring a nickel(II) Schiff base complex onto amino-modified MCM-41 (Entry 9). This catalyst displayed limited catalytic activity, achieving only 62 % conversion and 47 % selectivity, even at a higher temperature (80 °C) and a longer reaction duration (14 h) [62]. Moreover, the bi-functional metal oxide supported SBA-16 catalyst was prepared using a one-pot hydrothermal method. Specifically, 1 wt % of manganese nitrate tetrahydrate were uniformly mixed with the same weight percentages of ammonium tungsten oxide hydrate and dispersed on SBA-16 via the incipient wet impregnation method. The synthesized materials, MnWO4/SBA-16, were tested for the epoxidation of styrene resulting in maximum selectivity of about 75 % for styrene oxide (Entry 10) [63]. In another study, the CuONiO/SBA-15 catalyst (Entry 11) was prepared using a similar impregnation method. It demonstrated significant catalytic activity by achieving quantitative conversion with 92 % selectivity, but at a higher temperature of 80 °C and over 6 h [64]. Furthermore, MCM-41-supported Zr–Mn nanoparticles (Entry 12) were synthesized using a co-precipitation method, exhibiting lower conversion of 41 % with a selectivity of 78 % at a lower temperature of 40 °C for 7 h [65]. Overall, these comparisons clearly demonstrate that the heterogeneous catalysts SBA-15-N-ML1 developed in this study represent a significant improvement over previously reported systems, showcasing their effectiveness for styrene epoxidation. To gain a clearer understanding of the factors influencing the rate of the epoxidation reaction, several parameters were investigated, including time, temperature, the amount of catalyst, the concentration of TBHP, and UV light irradiation over SBA-15-N-CoL1 . 3.2.1 Effect of temperature The influence of temperature on the epoxidation of styrene to styrene oxide was investigated over SBA-15-CoL1 , with 2 equivalents of TBHP as the oxidant, under conditions previously described. The results, presented in Fig. 7 , revealed that as the temperature increased from 30 °C to 60 °C, both conversion and selectivity improved gradually. Specifically, the conversion increased from 35 % at 30 °C to 85 % at 60 °C, while selectivity rose from 39 % to 87 %. However, at temperatures exceeding 60 °C (specifically between 70 °C and 80 °C), the conversion experienced only a slight increase, reaching about 88 %, while selectivity showed a slight decline to approximately 83 %. Therefore, 60 °C was determined to be the optimal temperature, as further increases did not result in significant enhancements in either conversion or selectivity. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction time This study investigated the effect of varying reaction times on the epoxidation of styrene over the SBA-15-CoL1 catalyst with 2 equivalents of TBHP as the oxidant, under the previously described conditions. The results, shown in Fig. 8 , indicated that both the conversion of styrene and the selectivity for styrene oxide increased steadily from 2 h to 6 h. Notably, after 6 h, only a minor increase in selectivity was observed, with no significant change in conversion. At 4 h, conversion and selectivity reached 85 % and 87 %, respectively. Extending the reaction time to 6 h resulted in no notable improvement in conversion, although selectivity increased slightly to 90 %. Further increasing the reaction time to 8 h yielded only a slightly increase in selectivity to 92 %, without any change in conversion. 3.2.3 Effect of catalysts dose The influence of catalyst amount on the epoxidation of styrene was investigated using the SBA-15-N-CoL1 catalyst under previously established conditions, with 2 equivalents of TBHP as the oxidant. The results are illustrated in Fig. 9 . As the catalyst amount increased from 25 mg to 100 mg, both the conversion of styrene and the selectivity for styrene oxide showed a steady improvement. Specifically, conversion increased from 28 % to 90 %, while selectivity rose from 25 % to 92 %. However, when the catalyst amount was increased to 120 mg, no further enhancements in conversion or selectivity were observed. This decrease in catalytic activity may be attributed to potential catalyst aggregation or other effects that limit the accessibility of active sites. Consequently, the optimal catalyst dosage was determined to be 100 mg, beyond which additional catalyst did not enhance performance. 3.2.4 Effect of oxidant amount This investigation examined the effect of oxidant amount on the epoxidation of styrene over SBA-15-N-CoL1 catalyst. The catalyst was tested under optimized conditions with varying amounts of TBHP. The results are illustrated in Fig. 10 . As shown, 1 equivalent of TBHP was found to be inadequate for achieving low conversion of styrene. In contrast, 2 equivalents emerged as the optimal amount of TBHP for the SBA-15-N-CoL1 catalyst. This catalyst demonstrated impressive performance, achieving 85 % conversion and 87 % selectivity with 2 equivalents of TBHP. Moreover, increasing the amount of TBHP to 2.5 or 3 equivalents did not result in significant improvements in conversion or selectivity. Thus, 2 equivalents were identified as the optimal quantity. This finding aligns with previously reported literature, which indicated that a 1:1 substrate-to-oxidant mole ratio often leads to low catalytic activity due to insufficient oxidant for converting styrene into styrene epoxide [66]. 3.2.5 Effect of cis/trans conformation of the azobenzene moiety within the catalyst under UV–Vis irradiation The effect of azobenzene cis/trans isomerization on epoxidation of styrene over SBA-15-N-CoL1 was examined by performing this reaction after UV irradiation of the catalyst with 365 nm for 45 min, under the optimized conditions described above (i.e., Catalyst: 100 mg, TBHP: 2.0 eq, T: 60 °C). The obtained results are presented in Fig. 11 . Similar to the effect observed on the oxidation of cyclohexane [40], the UV irradiation, which induces the trans-to-cis isomerization of the azobenzene moiety within the catalysts, improved both the conversion of styrene and styrene oxide selectivity. Both conversion/selectivity were clearly increased after 4 h over catalysts SBA-15-N-CoL1 , from 82 % / 85 % before the UV irradiation, to 89 % / 91 % after UV irradiation, respectively. These results showed a positive effect of the cis conformation of the azobenzene moiety on the epoxidation reaction of styrene over these photochromic catalysts. The improved catalytic activity of the cis azobenzene isomer at shorter reaction times can be attributed to its reduced steric hindrance relative to the trans isomer. This characteristic facilitates easier access for substrates to the metal sites [67]. Furthermore, the cis conformation may offer greater conformational flexibility, which helps optimize substrate orientation for the reaction [68,69]. These steric and structural advantages, combined with a smaller HOMO-LUMO gap that is electronically favorable, enable the cis azobenzene isomer to catalyze the epoxidation of styrene more effectively than its trans counterpart [70–72]. 3.3 Catalyst reuse and stability The stability of the SBA15-N-CoL1 catalyst was evaluated through recycling and reuse across four consecutive runs under the optimized conditions mentioned earlier (i.e., Catalyst: 100 mg, Oxidant: 2 equivalents of TBHP, Reaction time: 4 h, Temperature: 60 °C). After each run, the spent catalyst was collected, washed, and dried. The results, shown in Fig. 12 a, indicate that the catalyst retained its high catalytic activity with only a slight reduction in conversion and selectivity, which can be attributed to the wall thickness of SBA-15 (3–6.5 nm). Furthermore, TEM image (Fig 12b) demonstrated that the mesoporous silica nanostructure remained intact after four runs, with no signs of metallic aggregation, suggesting the stability of the metal-N coordination bonds. ICP-MS analysis confirmed the catalyst's resistance to leaching, revealing Co content of 1.19 % for the fresh catalyst and 1.05 % for the spent catalyst, indicating no significant loss in metal content. Overall, the recycling results, along with the TEM images and ICP-MS analysis, underscore the robust stability of the developed SBA15-N-CoL1 . 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this research successfully demonstrates the potential of SBA-15-N-CoL₁ and SBA-15-N-MnL₁ as effective heterogeneous catalysts for the epoxidation of styrene. Both catalysts showed promising results; however, detailed studies on the effects of parameters such as temperature, reaction time, and the amounts of catalyst and TBHP were conducted only for SBA-15-N-CoL₁. The incorporation of photochromic azo groups into the metal-organic complexes not only enhances their catalytic properties but also provides unique light-responsive behavior, allowing for tunable activity under varying light conditions. The study highlights the advantages of using heterogeneous systems, such as ease of separation and reusability, which overcome key challenges faced by traditional homogeneous catalysts. The findings contribute significantly to the field of sustainable catalysis, emphasizing the potential for these novel catalysts in various industrial applications and open the way for further research into their optimization and practical use in green chemistry initiatives. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the epoxidation of styrene using efficient photochromic heterogeneous catalysts, specifically SBA-15-N-CoL₁ and SBA-15-N-MnL₁. Styrene oxide is a vital intermediate in the chemical industry, utilized in pharmaceuticals and polymers. Traditional homogeneous catalysts for styrene epoxidation face limitations, including difficulty in separation and recycling. This research focuses on the development of metal-organic complexes with photochromic properties to enhance catalytic efficiency and light responsiveness. Factors such as temperature, reaction time, amount of catalyst and an oxidant were systematically examined to optimize the catalytic performance. The results indicate that these heterogeneous catalysts achieved high conversion rates of styrene, with selectivity for styrene oxide reaching up to 85 %. Additionally, they demonstrated excellent stability and reusability, maintaining their catalytic activity over four consecutive cycles. This underscores their potential in promoting efficient chemical processes and advancing sustainable practices in the epoxidation of styrene.
